description: From Middle English snarlen, frequentative of snaren (“to trap, tangle”). Equivalent to snare +‎ -le.

entries.meaning: A knot or complication of hair, thread, or the like, difficult to disentangle.
An intricate complication; a problematic difficulty; a knotty or tangled situation.

verbs.description: snarl (third-person singular simple present snarls, present participle snarling, simple past and past participle snarled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To entangle; to complicate; to involve in knots.
examples: to snarl a skein of thread

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place in an embarrassing situation; to ensnare; to make overly complicated.
examples: [the] question that they would have snarled him with

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To be congested in traffic, or to make traffic congested.
To form raised work upon the outer surface of (thin metal ware) by the repercussion of a snarling iron upon the inner surface.

description: Frequentative of earlier snar (“to growl”), perhaps from Middle Low German snorren (“to drone”), of probably imitative origin. Equivalent to snar +‎ -le. Related to German schnarren (“to rattle”) and schnurren (“to hum, buzz”).

entries.meaning: The act of snarling; a growl; a surly or peevish expression; an angry contention.
A growl, for example that of an angry or surly dog, or similar; grumbling sounds.

verbs.description: snarl (third-person singular simple present snarls, present participle snarling, simple past and past participle snarled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To growl angrily by gnashing or baring the teeth; to gnarl; to utter grumbling sounds.
(transitive) To complain angrily; to utter growlingly.
(intransitive) To speak crossly; to talk in rude, surly terms.
examples: It is malicious and unmanly to snarl at the little lapses of a pen, from which Virgil himself stands not exempted.
